title: Feeding Therapy
shortDescription: Specialized therapy addressing eating difficulties, food aversions, and swallowing disorders.
description: Feeding therapy helps children who struggle with eating due to sensory sensitivities, oral motor difficulties, or behavioral challenges. Many children with autism experience significant feeding issues, including extreme food selectivity, texture aversions, and difficulty with chewing or swallowing. Feeding therapists, typically speech-language pathologists or occupational therapists with specialized training, work to expand food acceptance, improve oral motor skills, and create positive mealtime experiences. Therapy may address sensory processing, muscle coordination, and anxiety around new foods.
benefits: Expands variety of accepted foods and textures
Improves oral motor skills for safe chewing and swallowing
Reduces mealtime stress and anxiety for the whole family
Addresses sensory sensitivities related to food
Helps achieve adequate nutrition and healthy growth
whoCanBenefit: Children with extreme food selectivity or picky eating
Those with sensory aversions to food textures or temperatures
Children with oral motor or swallowing difficulties
Those who gag or vomit with new foods
Children with nutritional deficiencies due to limited diet
